Visa Types

Why Argentina?

Cost of Living Reality (2026)

Argentina is no longer 'cheap'—prices have doubled since 2023. Budget $1,500-3,000/month for a comparable lifestyle. Inflation has stabilized at 2-3% monthly under Milei, but costs are now Western Europe level.

Cultural Richness

From tango in Buenos Aires to gaucho traditions on the Pampas, indigenous heritage in the Northwest, and Welsh colonies in Patagonia — every region has its own distinct identity.

Extraordinary Natural Beauty

Iguazu Falls, Patagonian glaciers, Andean peaks, subtropical forests, salt flats, and Lake District vistas. No country on Earth offers more geographic diversity.

Visa Options (With Caveats)

Digital Nomad (180 days only), Rentista, and Investment visas available. DNI processing now takes 6+ months. Citizenship requires 2 years of permanent residency (4-5 years total). Research carefully before choosing.

Food and Wine Paradise

The world's best beef, Malbec wine regions, empanadas that vary by province, Italian-influenced cuisine, and a dining culture where meals are social events to be savored.

Welcoming Communities

Argentines are famously warm and social. Established expat communities exist across the country, from Buenos Aires to Bariloche, Mendoza to Salta.

Complete Guide Categories

Visas & Residency

Digital nomad, rentista, investor, and retirement visa guides with real application timelines.

Cost of Living

Monthly budgets for every major city, factoring in inflation, exchange rates, and the real costs.

Healthcare (2026 Rules)

Mandatory travel insurance required for entry. Public hospitals now charge foreigners. Prepaga system explained with updated 2026 pricing.

Housing & Rentals

Finding apartments without a garantia, rental contracts, and neighborhood guides for every city.

Banking & Money

Exchange rates, opening accounts, sending money internationally, and navigating the peso economy.

Safety

Real safety data by province and city, common scams to avoid, and practical precautions.

Transportation

Getting around Argentina—buses, flights, subways, and the SUBE card system.

Food & Dining

Argentine cuisine, restaurant etiquette, grocery shopping, and the dining culture.

Remote Work

Coworking spaces, internet speeds, and working remotely from Argentina.

Learn Spanish

Language schools, Rioplatense vs. standard Spanish, and immersion strategies that work.

Culture & Customs

Mate rituals, asado etiquette, and navigating Argentine social norms.

Expat Social Life

Meetup groups, language exchanges, sports clubs, and building your community.

Investment Opportunities

Real estate, agriculture, mining, energy, technology, and tourism investment sectors in Argentina.

Wine Guide

Argentine wine regions, grape varieties, buying tips, and tasting experiences from Mendoza to Salta.

City Guides

Featured Cities

Detailed guides for Argentina's most popular destinations for expats.

B
Buenos Aires
CABA

The Paris of South America. Argentina's pulsating capital offers world-class culture, dining, and nightlife with the largest expat community in the country.

M
Mendoza
Mendoza

Wine country paradise at the foot of the Andes. World-class Malbec, outdoor adventures, and 300 days of sunshine make this South America's answer to Napa Valley.

C
Córdoba
Córdoba

Argentina's university city and emerging tech hub. Young energy, affordable living, and stunning sierras make it the best-value big city in the country.

S
San Carlos de Bariloche
Río Negro

The 'Switzerland of South America.' Crystal-clear lakes, snow-capped peaks, artisan chocolate, and world-class skiing in the heart of Patagonia's Lake District.

S
Salta
Salta

Salta la Linda — colonial charm, desert landscapes, world-famous empanadas, and the most affordable city living in Argentina. The Northwest's crown jewel.

R
Rosario
Santa Fe

Argentina's third city — birthplace of the flag, Che Guevara, and Messi. A river city with a growing cosmopolitan scene, great food, and BA vibes at half the price.

View All Cities

Argentina's 6 Regions

From subtropical jungles to Antarctic glaciers, Argentina has it all.

Patagonia

Glaciers, lakes, and the end of the world

Cuyo

Wine country and Andean adventures

Northwest

Indigenous culture and desert landscapes

Northeast

Waterfalls, wetlands, and subtropical forests

Pampas

Endless plains and gaucho culture

Central

Urban hubs and university cities

What expats say about living in Argentina

“I moved to Buenos Aires with $2,000/month income and live comfortably. The exchange rate means I can afford a nice apartment in Palermo, eat out regularly, and still save money. Quality of life is incredible.”

R

Rachel

Remote Worker · From USA

“The startup ecosystem in Buenos Aires surprised me. Great talent, lower costs than Europe, and a city that actually feels alive 24/7. Wish I'd moved here sooner.”

L

Luis

Entrepreneur · From Spain

“Studied at UBA for a year. Cost of living was half what I paid in London. Learned Spanish, made friends from all over Latin America, traveled to Patagonia and Iguazu. Best year of my life.”

E

Emma

Student · From UK
